H0.text: The uppermost complete row of the table is where the most reactive metals are located on the periodic table.

H1.text: The rows at the bottom of the table connecting two sections are where the most reactive metals are located on the periodic table.

H2.text: The column at the far left side of the periodic table is where the most reactive metals are located.

H3.text: The second column from the right side of the table is where the most reactive metals are located on the periodic table.

A4.text: The alkali metals are all shiny, soft, highly reactive metals at standard temperature and pressure and readily lose their outermost electron to form cations with charge +1. Together with hydrogen they constitute group 1, which lies in the sâ€‘block of the periodic table.

A5.text: Caesium, the fifth alkali metal, is the most reactive of all the metals.
